name: Desktop Environment Software Development
description: Install and configure the necessary packages and tools required to develop graphical applications for various desktop environments such as GNOME, KDE (Frameworks 5 and 6), and Xfce. This feature encapsulates the development setups for GTK+, Qt, and their respective frameworks to ensure seamless application creation and integration with target environments. It covers GNOME, KDE, and Xfce development needs.

name: System Management and Diagnostics Suite
description: A comprehensive collection of tools and utilities designed to manage, monitor, debug, and optimize systems, applications, and networks. This suite provides a unified framework for system administration, performance diagnostics, security auditing, and accessibility across desktops, servers, and large-scale computing environments. The feature set includes graphical and console-based utilities to support diverse workflows, including headless management, hardware monitoring, network analysis, security testing, and mainframe connectivity. It is tailored to meet the requirements of both workstation and enterprise environments with a focus on performance, security, and reliability.

name: Desktop Environment Selection
description: A collection of desktop environments designed to provide various user experiences and functionalities for Linux-based operating systems. This feature encompasses environments for both phone/tablet and traditional desktop setups, ranging from lightweight and resource-efficient solutions to feature-rich and elegant designs. Users can choose from a variety of graphical interfaces tailored for different use cases and preferences.

name: Cross-Platform Compatibility and Legacy Support
description: This parent feature encompasses tools, libraries, and programs necessary for ensuring compatibility and interoperability across multiple platforms and environments. It includes support for legacy systems, cross-platform development, and integration with non-native platform ecosystems. The sub-features in this group address compatibility with older Linux versions, legacy UNIX and X Window systems, the Java Platform, Windows file sharing, and cross-compilation targets.

name: Comprehensive Linux Software Suite
description: A unified collection of versatile software tools and environments designed for diverse domains, including education, science, engineering, media production, technical writing, and entertainment. This suite offers robust support for professionals, educators, students, and enthusiasts, catering to creative, scientific, and practical computing needs. By combining high-performing toolkits, specialized programming environments, and user-friendly graphical and desktop solutions, this integrated feature set provides an all-in-one platform for productivity, learning, and innovation.

name: Infrastructure and Cloud Management Tools
description: A comprehensive set of tools and software packages designed to manage, optimize, and enhance the functionality of IT infrastructure, cloud environments, virtualized systems, and high-availability services. This feature encompasses solutions for creating, managing, and maintaining backups, enabling cloud-based deployments, managing containers, virtualization, and supporting remote management, clustering, and high-performance connectivity.

name: Critical Path Functionality
description: The 'Critical Path Functionality' parent feature encompasses a cohesive set of packages and applications that are fundamental to the proper functioning, building, and deployment of Linux platforms, across various editions, desktops, spins, and use cases. This feature ensures that mission-critical tasks and components are supported, providing a reliable and consistent foundation for Linux distributions. It includes the core base platform, build systems, application functionality, and desktop environment integration, alongside tools for installation and deployments for specialized use cases such as servers. By consolidating these sub-features, the parent feature encapsulates all essential packages and applications pivotal to the stability, usability, and delivery of Linux systems in diverse scenarios.

name: Server and Network Services
description: A comprehensive feature group encompassing various server and network service capabilities that allow the system to provide core infrastructure services such as email, file sharing, printing, web hosting, and news services. This feature enables the configuration, deployment, and management of server roles for robust network functionality and seamless client-server interactions.

name: Enhanced Desktop and Development Environment
description: A comprehensive feature encompassing tools and packages designed to enhance desktop usage, support accessibility, and aid in software development. This feature aggregates groups aimed at professional designers, developers, and users requiring a robust graphical environment, while also including essential legacy and compatibility resources. It ensures a seamless experience for graphical and software development tasks across modern and legacy systems.

name: Linux Product Core and OSTree Support
description: This parent feature encompasses essential package support and configuration for various Linux-based product lines, ensuring core functionality, OSTree integration, and scalability across different environments. It includes mandatory system packages required to support Atomic Host OSTree operations, in addition to aligning essential package sets for the Linux Client, ComputeNode, Server, and Workstation products. Furthermore, it incorporates dedicated OSTree support for the Linux Workstation product to meet advanced use case requirements and system consistency.

name: Virtualization Support Ecosystem
description: A comprehensive suite of features and packages that enable, optimize, and manage virtualization environments across various platforms and scenarios, covering everything from minimal installations to complete graphical virtualization management interfaces. This parent feature encompasses utilities, drivers, agents, and tools required for supporting virtualized hosts, guests, desktops, hypervisor platforms, and associated network configurations, ensuring seamless integration in diverse virtualization infrastructures.

name: Database Management Systems
description: This feature encompasses various database management systems and tools, including relational database systems, database clients, and related technologies. It includes support for products from Alibaba, MariaDB, PostgreSQL, and openGauss, covering a wide range of database functionalities such as database server implementations, client interfaces, and platform-specific tools.

name: Conflicts Management for Installation Variants and Repositories
description: This parent feature encompasses the identification and management of package conflicts that arise during '@everything' installations across various system variants and repositories. It includes sub-features addressing specific conflicts for installation profiles such as Client, ComputeNode, Server, and Workstation, as well as detailed conflict resolution for packages sourced from AppStream and BaseOS repositories. The main goal is to ensure compatibility and smooth deployment by resolving package conflicts effectively within diverse installation scenarios.

name: Desktop Environment Office and Productivity Suites
description: A comprehensive category that includes various office and productivity suites tailored for specific Linux desktop environments and general-purpose productivity tools. This feature encompasses office suite integrations for desktop environments such as Deepin Desktop, LXDE, LXQt, and Xfce, as well as standalone productivity solutions like LibreOffice and broader office suite applications.

name: Graphical User Interface and Window Management
description: A comprehensive feature encompassing support for graphical user interfaces and window management environments. This feature includes basic support for the X Window System, tiling and stacking window managers, and supplemental packages for enhanced functionality. It provides a flexible range of options, from minimal setups for advanced users to easily configurable environments for general users.

name: System and Networking Tools Suite
description: A comprehensive collection of tools and packages designed to manage system administration, hardware support, software development, network management, scientific computation, and specialized use cases such as robotics, font design, and server configurations. This suite provides both graphical and command-line utilities to simplify system operations, enhance productivity, and support a diverse range of functionalities across engineering, scientific, and server-related domains.

name: Comprehensive Linux Development Toolkit
description: A consolidated environment providing tools, libraries, and resources necessary for a wide range of software development tasks on Linux. This includes core utilities for system development, application construction, .NET Core development, platform optimization, and open-source package management. It integrates specialized tooling for diverse programming languages (e.g., C, D), compatibility layers, packaging utilities like RPM tools, and additional features tailored for environments such as Sugar and Fedora. Designed to cater to developers seeking a robust and adaptable development toolkit on the Linux platform.

name: Identity and Security Management
description: A comprehensive suite of features for managing identities, access control, authentication, and security in a networked environment. This parent feature encompasses tools and services for integrating machines and users into directory services, enforcing secure authentication methods, managing certificates, and providing centralized domain membership and identity management functionality. It also includes mechanisms for ensuring system integrity and trust through advanced security tools.

name: Desktop Environment Applications and Enhancements
description: A comprehensive collection of applications, media packages, and additional enhancements tailored for various Linux desktop environments. This feature encapsulates a variety of essential and recommended tools, games, and media components to enrich the user experience across multiple desktop environments, including LXDE, Budgie, GNOME, and Deepin.
children: Extra games for the GNOME Desktop

name: Text and Document Authoring and Internet Communication Tools
description: This feature encompasses tools and systems used for creating, editing, formatting, and publishing documents, as well as applications for internet communication. It includes software for text editing, document preparation, input methods for diverse languages, and interactive tools for internet-based tasks. The feature also integrates systems that facilitate the visual representation of text through appropriate fonts and methods for rendering. Additionally, it covers functionalities for email communication in both graphical and text-based formats.

name: Desktop Environment Multimedia and Plugin Support
description: A comprehensive feature that encompasses multimedia support and extended functionality through plugins for various Linux desktop environments. This feature integrates functionalities such as multimedia playback, audio/video frameworks, CD recording, and plugin extensions for desktop panels to enhance usability and user experience. It ensures seamless multimedia compatibility and panel extensibility for popular desktop environments, including KDE, Xfce, LXDE, and LXQt, while also supporting cross-platform multimedia frameworks like VideoLAN.
children: Extra plugins for the Xfce panel

name: Network and Infrastructure Services
description: This feature encompasses a comprehensive set of services designed to provide network and infrastructure functionalities. It includes the ability to run DNS name services, manage file and storage services, support legacy network protocols, enable load balancing for network traffic, facilitate core network infrastructure protocols, provide key network-based functionalities like DHCP servers, and manage resilient or clustered storage for high availability. These services are essential for building robust, scalable, and resilient networked environments.

name: Web and Application Hosting Framework
description: This parent feature represents a comprehensive framework for hosting, managing, and running web applications, scripting languages, and application servers. It includes support for load balancing, web browsers, and several web development technologies. The framework covers a wide variety of tools and technologies to enable scalable, dynamic, and efficient web service delivery. This feature ensures compatibility and integration for hosting modern web applications and frameworks, as well as providing an optimized environment for development and deployment.

name: Programming Language Support
description: Comprehensive support for developing and running software using a variety of programming languages, including their associated libraries, interfaces, and development tools. This feature ensures a broad range of functionality for both fundamental language execution and advanced development requirements in programming environments such as Haskell, Java (runtime and development), OCaml, Perl, and Ruby.

name: Lightweight Desktop Environments and Applications
description: A collection of lightweight desktop environments and associated applications designed for low-resource or hardware-constrained systems. This includes the LXQt and LXDE desktop environments, translations for LXQt, and additional applications optimized for the LXQt desktop. The collection also introduces Enlightenment, a lean and efficient desktop environment for similar use cases.

name: Desktop Environment Features and Applications
description: A comprehensive set of features and applications tailored for various desktop environments, including Xfce, GNOME, and KDE. This parent feature encapsulates essential components, applications, and utilities that enhance usability, functionality, and personalization across different desktop environments. It includes workspace setups, commonly used applications, educational tools, office suites, personal information management tools, and configuration packages for initial system setup.
